filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of a digital edition of A Descriptive Catalogue of Pictures, Poetical and Historical Inventions, Painted by William Blake, in Water Colours, Being the Ancient Method of Fresco Painting Restored: and [water color] Drawings, For Public Inspection, and for Sale by Private Contract. Printed by a job printer in a small run, perhaps fewer than one hundred copies, the catalogue accompanied his self-organized one-man exhibition of 1809-10. It hung in the rooms above his brother’s haberdashery shop in Soho—Blake’s childhood home. The price of the catalogue included admission to the exhibition.
British artists spent much of the later eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries struggling to find viable commercial outlets. Lamenting that they lacked the infrastructure of patronage, exhibition, and refined understanding that supported Continental artists, they promoted the formation of new institutions, such as the Royal Academy and the British Institution, to add gravity and legitimacy to match commercial opportunity. Commercial gallery schemes such as Boydell’s Shakspeare Gallery were popular if unsuccessful marketing experiments. Diverse individual and group exhibitions, both fixed and traveling, were attempted in locales from Green Park to the Royal Academy to the homes of individual artists, such as J. M. W. Turner, who devoted domestic space to the exhibition of their work. Descriptive catalogues and other printed documentation were a regular part of these innovations in art marketing.
Blake’s catalogue describes sixteen pictures, nine in his version of “portable fresco” (gum- or glue-based tempera), seven in water color—several of those borrowed from his patron Thomas Butts. The exhibition was anchored by two of the temperas, Sir Jeffery Chaucer and the Nine and Twenty Pilgrims on Their Journey to Canterbury—described perceptively in considerable detail and afterwards engraved—and The Ancient Britons, by far the largest painting Blake ever executed. It and four others are now lost.
Henry Crabb Robinson later characterized Blake’s catalogue as a “veritable folio of fragmentary utterances on art and religion, without plan or arrangement” (Blake Records page 450). Rhetorically, it is a high decibel, cacophonous, aggressive amalgam of painting by painting descriptions punctuated with strong statements of artistic principle colored by enthusiasm, resentment, blame, and defensiveness, sharpened by hints of conspiracy, technical description, and assorted other forays, often within a single entry. Blake makes his usual appeal “to the Public”—the authentic, idealized public in which he consistently claims to have faith—as a refuge from the villains of commerce, politics, and bad art.
It is easy to see why Robert (brother of Leigh) Hunt, the only reviewer, charged Blake, “an unfortunate lunatic,” with having produced “a farrago of nonsense, unintelligibleness, and egregious vanity, the wild effusions of a distempered brain” (The Examiner 17 Sept. 1809, Blake Records page 283). But Charles Lamb, tolerant of eccentricity, was “delighted” with the catalogue, according to Crabb Robinson (Blake Records page 694). Of course, the crusade that Blake attempted to launch with his exhibition was in one sense mad—or at least hopelessly quixotic, yet another dismal failure to secure recognition, respect, and income. We have no attendance records, but what slender evidence there is suggests that the exhibition and catalogue attracted little other than sufficient public mockery and scorn to wound and infuriate Blake once again.
But, more broadly, the exhibition signaled a pivot from the battered hopes of an inventive youth and middle age—years when Blake was often able to claim some of Britain’s best artists as supporters, despite a string of major disappointments—into his last two decades, ultimately brightened by the appearance of a new generation of artistically sympathetic young admirers and sponsors. The catalogue and the exhibition it registers are products of new, or renewed, artistic ideas and projects, bolstered by a determination to crusade openly for the reformation of British art—to eliminate its commercialism and return (as Blake imagined it) to older, purer, original forms of expression represented by Michelangelo and Raphael, who he thought united conception and execution in coherent lines lost by modern British oil portraitists such as Joshua Reynolds, whose elaborate effects of tone and color were mere pretty, superficial distractions from the impoverished, incoherent—in Blake’s lexicon, blurred and blotted—visions beneath them. The 1809 exhibition and catalogue aim to call Reynolds’s bluff, as it were, by showing modern artists and audiences how to shed the hypocrisies of blotting and blurring and return to the truth of vision expressed in media, such as “the Ancient Method of Fresco Painting Restored,” that could bear the weight of truth.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

objinfo.medium: type with handwritten corrections in pen and ink
objinfo.binding: Originally issued in wrappers, possibly grayish-blue as in copies C, G, and K. Rebound no later than 1890 in brown levant morocco by F. Bedford, with gilt frames on covers and stamped in gilt on the spine.

provenance.name: Huntington Library
provenance.note: Sold with the Robert Arthington Library at Sotheby's to "James" on 17 May 1866, lot 21 for £1.9*s*; listed in T. G. Arthur's *Catalogue* (1890), 15 and sold with his library at Sotheby's on 15 July 1914, lot 45 for £24.10*s*. to G.D. Smith; sold by Smith no later than 1920 to Henry E. Huntington for $350 and now in the Huntington Library.

II2. The Pictures and Drawings to remain
in the Exhibition till its close, which will be
the 29th of September 1809; and the Picture
of the Canterbury Pilgrims, which is to be en-engraved
gravedengraved, will be Sold only on condition of its re-remaining
mainingremaining in the Artist's hands twelve months,
when it will be delivered to the Buyer.

lg.l: THE eye that can prefer the ColouringColoring of
Titian and Rubens to that of Michael AngeloMichelangelo
and RafaelRaphael, ought to be modest and to doubt its
own powers. Connoisseurs talk as if Rafael Raphael
and Michael AngeloMichelangelo had never seen the Colour– Colouring
ingColouring of Titian and Correggio: They ought to
know that Correggio was born two years be– before
forebefore Michael AngeloMichelangelo, and Titian but four years
after. Both Rafael Raphael and Michael Angelo Michelangelo knew
the Venetian, and contemned and rejected all
he did with the utmost disdain, as that which
is fabricated for the purpose to destroy art.
Mr. B. Blake appeals to the Public, from the
judgement of those narrow blinking eyes, that
have too long governed art in a dark corner.
The eyes of stupid cunning never will be
pleased with the work any more than with the
look of self-devoting genius. The quarrel of
the Florentine with the Venetian is not because
he does not understand Drawing, but because
he does not understand ColouringColoring. How

should he? he who does not know how to drawBentley emends "How should he? he who..." to "How should he who..." noting that "the question mark belongs at the end of the sentence, and the extra 'he' should be removed" (*Writings* volume 2 pages 827n4 and 1694n2).
a hand or a foot, know how to colourcolor it.
ColouringColoring does not depend on where the
ColoursColors are put, but on where the lights and
darks are put, and all depends on Form or
Outline. On where that is put; where that
is wrong, the ColouringColoring never can be right;
and it is always wrong in Titian and Correggio,
Rubens and Rembrandt. Till we get rid of
Titian and Correggio, Rubens and Rembrandt,
We never shall equal Rafael Raphael and Albert DurerAlbrecht Durer,
Michael AngeloMichelangelo>, and JulioGiulio> Romano.
NUMBER I1.

l.hi: The spiritual form of Nelson guiding Leviathan,
in whose wreathings are infoldedenfolded the Nations
of the Earth.

lg.l: CLEARNESS and precision have been the chief
objects in painting these Pictures. Clear
colourscolors unmudded by oil, and firm and deter– determinate
minatedeterminate lineaments unbroken by shadows,
which ought to display and not to hide form,
as is the practice of the latter Schools of
Italy and Flanders.

desc.objtitle: Page 2, Number II2, Its Companion, Object 6 (Bentley 2)

lg.l: NUMBER II2, ITS COMPANION

l.hi: The spiritual form of Pitt, guiding Behemoth;
he is that Angel who, pleased to perform the
Almighty's orders, rides on the whirlwind,
directing the storms of war: He is ordering
the Reaper to reap the Vine of the Earth,
and the Plowman to plow up the Cities and
Towers.

lg.l: THIS Picture also is a proof of the power of
colourscolors unsullied with oil or with any cloggy
vehicle. Oil has falsely been supposed to give
strength to colourscolors: but a little consideration
must shew show the fallacy of this opinion. Oil
will not drink or absorb colourcolor enough to stand
the test of very little time and of the air. It
deadens every colourcolor it is mixed with, at its
first mixture, and in a little time becomes a
yellow mask over all that it touches. Let the
works of modern Artists since Rubens' time
witness the villany villainy of some one at that time,
who first brought oil Painting into general
opinion and practice: since which we have
never had a Picture painted, that could shew show
itself by the side of an earlier production.
Whether Rubens or Vandykevan Dyck, or both, were
guilty of this villanyvillainy, is to be enquired in an– another
otheranother work on Painting, and who first forged
the silly story and known falshoodfalsehood, about John
of Bruges inventing oil colourscolors: in the mean
time let it be observed, that before Van– van Dyck van Dyck
dyke'svan Dyck time, and in his time all the genuine
Pictures are on Plaster or Whiting grounds
and none since.
The two Pictures of Nelson and Pitt are
compositions of a mythological cast, similar to
those Apotheoses of Persian, HindooHindu, and Egyp– Egyptian
tianEgyptian Antiquity, which are still preserved on
rude monuments, being copies from some stu– stupendous
pendousstupendous originals now lost or perhaps buried
till some happier age. The Artist having been
taken in vision into the ancient republics, mo– monarchies
narchiesmonarchies, and patriarchates of Asia, has seen those
wonderful originals called in the Sacred Scrip– Scriptures
turesScriptures the Cherubim, which were sculptured and
painted on walls of Temples, Towers, Cities,
Palaces, and erected in the highly cultivated
states of Egypt, Moab, Edom, Aram, among
the Rivers of Paradise, being originals from
which the Greeks and Hetrurians copied Her– Hercules
culesHercules, Farnese, Venus of MedicisMedici, Apollo Bel– Belvedere
videreBelvidere, and all the grand works of ancient art.
They were executed in a very superior style
to those justly admired copies, being with
their accompaniments terrific and grand in
the highest degree. The Artist has endeavour– endeavoured
edendeavoured to emulate the grandeur of those seen in
his vision, and to apply it to modern Heroes,
on a smaller scale.
No man can believe that either Homer's
Mythology, or Ovid's, were the production of
Greece, or of Latium; neither will any one
believe, that the Greek statues, as they are
called, were the invention of Greek Artists;
perhaps the Torso is the only original work
remaining; all the rest are evidently copies,
though fine ones, from greater works of the
Asiatic Patriarchs. The Greek Muses are
daughters of Mnemosyne, or Memory, and not
of Inspiration or Imagination, therefore not
authors of such sublime conceptions. Those
wonderful originals seen in my visions, were
some of them one hundred feet in height;
some were painted as pictures, and some carv– carved
edcarved as basso relievos, and some as groupes groups of sta– statues
tuesstatues, all containing mythological and recon– recondite
diterecondite meaning, where more is meant than meets
the eye. The Artist wishes it was now the
fashion to make such monuments, and then
he should not doubt of having a national com– commision
misioncommision to execute these two Pictures on a
scale that is suitable to the grandeur of the
nation, who is the parent of his heroes, in high
finished fresco, where the colourscolors would be as
pure and as permanent as precious stones
though the figures were one hundred feet in
height.
All Frescos are as high finished as miniatures
or enamels, and they are known to be un– unchangeable
changeableunchangeable; but oil being a body itself, will
drink or absorb very little colourcolor, and chang– changing
ingchanging yellow, and at length brown, destroys
every colourcolor it is mixed with, especially every
delicate colourcolor. It turns every permanent
white to a yellow and brown putty, and has
compelled the use of that destroyer of colourcolor,
white lead; which, when its protecting oil is
evaporated, will become lead again. This is
an awful thing to say to oil Painters; they may
call it madness, but it is true. All the genuine
old little Pictures, called Cabinet Pictures, are
in fresco and not in oil. Oil was not used ex– except
ceptexcept by blundering ignorance, till after Van– van Dyck
dykeVandyke's time, but the art of fresco painting
being lost, oil became a fetter to genius, and a
dungeon to art. But one convincing proof
among many others, that these assertions are
true is, that real gold and silver cannot be
used with oil, as they are in all the old pictures
and in Mr. B. Blake 's frescos.
NUMBER III3.

l.hi:
Sir
Jeffery
Geoffrey
Chaucer and the nine and twenty
Pilgrims on their journey to Canterbury.

lg.l: THE time chosen is early morning, before sun–sunrise
risesunrise, when the jolly company are just quitting
the Tabarde Inn. The Knight and Squire
with the Squire's Yeoman lead the Procession,
next follow the youthful Abbess, her nun and
three priests; her greyhounds attend her.
"Of small hounds had she that fed
"With roast flesh, milk and wastel bread."The original text reads "rost" rather than "roast" and "wastell" instead of "wastel" (Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").
Next follow the Friar and Monk; then the
Tapiser, the Pardoner, and the SomnerSummoner and
Manciple. After these "Our Host," who oc–occupies
cupiesoccupies the center of the cavalcade; directs
them to the Knight as the person who would
be likely to commence their task of each tell–telling
ingtelling a tale in their order. After the Host fol–follow
lowfollow the Shipman, the Haberdasher, the Dyer,
the Franklin, the Physician, the Plowman, the
Lawyer, the poor Parson, the Merchant, the
Wife of Bath, the Miller, the Cook, the Ox–Oxford
fordOxford Scholar, Chaucer himself, and the Reeve
comes as Chaucer has described:
"And ever he rode hinderest of the rout."The original text reads "route" rather than "rout" (Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").
These last are issuing from the gateway of the
Inn; the Cook and the Wife of Bath are both
taking their morning's draught of comfort.
Spectators stand at the gateway of the Inn,
and are composed of an old Man, a Woman
and Children.
The Landscape is an eastward view of the
country, from the Tabarde Inn, in Southwark,
as it may be supposed to have appeared in
Chaucer's time; interspersed with cottages and
villages; the first beams of the Sun are seen
above the horizon; some buildings and spires
indicate the situation of the great City, the
Inn is a gothic building, which Thynne in his
Glossary says was the lodging of the Abbot
of Hyde, by Winchester. On the Inn is in–inscribed
scribedinscribed its title, and a proper advantage is taken
of this circumstance to describe the subject
of the Picture. The words written over the
gateway of the Inn, are as follow: "The Ta–Tabarde
bardeTabarde Inn, by Henry Baillie, the lodgynge–lodging
house for Pilgrims, who journey to Saint
Thomas's Shrine at Canterbury."
The characters of Chaucer's Pilgrims are
the characters which compose all ages and na–nations
tionsnations: as one age falls, another rises, different
to mortal sight, but to immortals only the
same; for we see the same characters repeated
again and again, in animals, vegetables, mine–minerals
ralsminerals, and in men; nothing new occurs in iden–identical
ticalidentical existence; Accident ever varies, Sub–Substance
stanceSubstance can never suffer change nor decay.
Of Chaucer's characters, as described in his
Canterbury Tales, some of the names or titles
are altered by time, but the characters them–themselves
selvesthemselves for ever remain unaltered, and conse–consequently
quentlyconsequently they are the physiognomies or linea–lineaments
mentslineaments of universal human life, beyond which
Nature never steps. Names alter, things
never alter. I have known multitudes of those
who would have been monks in the age of
monkery, who in this deistical age are deists.
As Newton numbered the stars, and as Linneus
numbered the plants, so Chaucer numbered
the classes of men.
The Painter has consequently varied the
heads and forms of his personages into all Na–
ture's varieties; the Horses he has also varied
to accord to their Riders, the Costume is cor–correct
rectcorrect according to authentic monuments.
The Knight and the Squire with the Squire's
Yeoman lead the procession, as Chaucer has also
placed them first in his prologue. The Knight is
a true Hero, a good, great, and wise man; his
whole length portrait on horseback, as written
by Chaucer, cannot be surpassed. He has spentThere is a stray mark after "by". Probably a typographical variation.
his life in the field; has ever been a conqueror,
and is that species of character which in
every age stands as the guardian of man
against the oppressor. His son is like him with
the germ of perhaps greater perfection still,
as he blends literature and the arts with his
warlike studies. Their dress and their horses
are of the first rate, without ostentation, and
with all the true grandeur that unaffected sim–plicity
plicitysimplicity when in high rank always displays.
The Squire's Yeoman is also a great character,
a man perfectly knowing in his profession:
"And in his hand he bare a mighty bow."The original text reads "mightie" rather than "mighty" (Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").
Chaucer describes here a mighty man; one
who in war is the worthy attendant on noble
heroes.
The Prioress follows these with her female
chaplain.
"Another Nonne also with her had she,
"That was her Chaplaine and Priests three."The original text reads "Chapleine" rather than "Chaplaine" (Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").
This Lady is described also as of the first
rank; rich and honouredhonored. She has certain
peculiarities and little delicate affectations, not
unbecoming in her, being accompanied with
what is truly grand and really polite; her person
and face, Chaucer has described with minute–minuteness
nessminuteness; it is very elegant, and was the beauty of
our ancestors, till after Elizabeth's time, when
voluptuousness and folly began to be account–accounted
edaccounted beautiful.
Her companion and her three priests were no
doubt all perfecty delineated in those parts of
Chaucer's work which are now lost; we ought
to suppose them suitable attendants on rank
and fashion.
The Monk follows these with the Friar.
The Painter has also grouped with these, the
Pardoner and the SompnourSummoner and the Manciple,
and has here also introduced one of the rich
citizens of London. Characters likely to ride
in company, all being above the common rank
in life or attendants on those who were so.
For the Monk is described by Chaucer, as
a man of the first rank in society, noble, rich,
and expensively attended: he is a leader of
the age, with certain humourous accompani–accompaniments
mentsaccompaniments in his character, that do not degrade,
but render him an object of dignified mirth,
but also with other accompaniments not so
respectable.
The Friar is a character also of a mixed kind.
"A friar there was, a wanton and a merry."The original text reads "frere" rather than "friar" (Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").

ut in his office he is said to be a "full solemnBentley inserts a “[B]” in front of the letters “ut” and suggests that “the b dropped out of ‘but’” (*Writings* volume 2 pages 836 and 1694n14). The original text reads "solempne" rather than "solemn" (Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").
man:" eloquent, amorous, witty and satyri–satyrical
C
calsatirical; young, handsome, and rich; he is a com–complete
pletecomplete rogue; with constitutional gaiety enough
to make him a master of all the pleasures of
the world.
"His neck was white as the flour de lis,The original text reads "floure delice" rather than "flour de lis" (Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").
Thereto strong he was as a champiounchampion."
It is necessary here to speak of Chaucer's
own character, that I may set certain mistaken
critics right in their conception of the humourhumor
and fun that occurs on the journey. Chaucer
is himself the great poetical observer of men,
who in every age is born to record and eter–eternize
nizeeternize its acts. This he does as a master, as a
father, and superior, who looks down on their
little follies from the Emperor to the Miller;
sometimes with severity, oftener with joke and
sport.
Accordingly Chaucer has made his Monk a
great tragedian, one who studied poetical art.
So much so, that the generous Knight is, in the
compassionate dictates of his soul, compelled
to cry out
"Ho quoth the KnyghtKnight, good Sir, no more of this,The original text reads "qd.the knight" rather than "quoth the Knyght" (Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").
That ye have said, is right ynough I wis;The original text reads "iwis" rather than "wis" (Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").
And mokell more, for little heaviness,The original text reads "mokel" rather than "mokell" (Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").

Is right enough for much folk as I guesse.The original text reads "inough" rather than "enough," "folke" rather than "folk," and "gesse" rather than "guesse" (Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").
I say for me, it is a great disease,
Whereas men have been in wealth and ease;The original text reads "be in welth" rather than "been in wealth" (Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").
To hearehear of their sudden fall alas,The original text reads "her suddaine" rather than "their sudden" (Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").
And the contrary is joy and solassolace."
The Monk's definition of tragedy in the
proem to his tale is worth repeating:
"TragedieTragedy is to tell a certain story,The original text reads "certaine" rather than "certain" (Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").
As old books us maken memory;The original text reads "bookes" rather than "books" and "memorie" rather than "memory" (Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").
Of hem that stood in great prosperity.The original text reads "prosperitie" rather than "prosperity" (Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").
And be fallen out of high degree,The original text reads "hie" rather than "high" (Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").
Into miseriemisery and ended wretchedly."
Though a man of luxury, pride and plea–pleasure
surepleasure, he is a master of art and learning, though
affecting to despise it. Those who can think
that the proud Huntsman, and noble House–Housekeeper
keeperHousekeeper, Chaucer's Monk, is intended for a buf–buffoon
foonbuffoon or a burlesque character, know little of
Chaucer.
For the Host who follows this group, and
holds the center of the cavalcade, is a first rate
character, and his jokes are no trifles; they
are always, though uttered with audacity, and
equally free with the Lord and the Peasant,
they are always substantially and weightily ex–expressive
pressiveexpressive of knowledge and experience; Henry
Baillie, the keeper of the greatest Inn, of the
greatest City; for such was the Tabarde Inn in
Southwark, near London: our Host was also a
leader of the age.
By way of illustration, I instance Shaks–Shakespeare
peareShakespeare's Witches in Macbeth. Those who dress
them for the stage, consider them as wretched
old women, and not as ShakspeareShakespeare intended,
the Goddesses of Destiny; this shewsshows how
Chaucer has been misunderstood in his sublime
work. ShakspeareShakespeare's Fairies also are the
rulers of the vegetable world, and so are Chau–Chaucer
cerChaucer's; let them be so considered, and then the
poet will be understood, and not else.
But I have omitted to speak of a very promi–prominent
nentprominent character, the Pardoner, the Age's Knave,
who always commands and domineers over the
high and low vulgar. This man is sent in
every age for a rod and scourge, and for a
blight, for a trial of men, to divide the classes
of men, he is in the most holy sanctuary, and
he is suffered by Providence for wise ends, and
has also his great use, and his grand leading
destiny.
His companion the SompnourSummoner, is also a Devil
of the first magnitude, grand, terrific, rich
and honouredhonored in the rank of which he holds
the destiny. The uses to society are perhaps
equal of the Devil and of the Angel, their
sublimity who can dispute.
"In daunger had he at his own gise,The original text reads "owne" rather than "own" (Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").
The young girls of his diocese,The original text reads "yong girles" rather than "young girls," and "Diocise" rather than "diocese" (Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").

And he knew well their counsel, &c."Bentley suggests that the double quotation mark after "&c." is printed using "an apostrophe and a single quotation mark" (*Writings* volume 2 pages 838n34 and 1694n17). The original text reads "knew her counsaile, and was of her read" rather than "knew well their counsel, &c." (Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").
The principal figure in the next groupegroup, is
the Good Parson; an Apostle, a real Messen–Messenger
gerMessenger of Heaven, sent in every age for its light
and its warmth. This man is beloved and ve–venerated
neratedvenerated by all, and neglected by all: He
serves all, and is served by none; he is, ac–according
cordingaccording to Christ's definition, the greatest of
his age. Yet he is a Poor Parson of a town.
Read Chaucer's description of the Good Par–Parson
sonParson, and bow the head and the knee to him,
who, in every age sends us such a burning and
a shining light. Search O ye rich and power–powerful
fulpowerful, for these men and obey their counsel, then
shall the golden age return: But alas! you
will not easily distinguish him from the Friar
or the Pardoner, they are also "full solemn
men," and their counsel, you will continue to
follow.
I have placed by his side, the Sergeant at
Lawe, who appears delighted to ride in his
company, and between him and his brother,
the Plowman; as I wish men of Law would
always ride with them, and take their counsel,
especially in all difficut points. Chaucer's
Lawyer is a character of great venerableness,
a Judge, and a real master of the jurispru–jurisprudence
dencejurisprudence of his age.
The Doctor of Physic is in this groupegroup,
and the Franklin, the voluptuous country
gentleman, contrasted wth the Physician,
and on his other hand, with two Citizens of
London. Chaucer's characters live age after
age. Every age is a Canterbury Pilgrimage;
we all pass on, each sustaining one or other
of these characters; nor can a child be born,
who is not one of these characters of Chaucer.
The Doctor of Physic is described as the first
of his profession; perfect, learned, com–completely
pletelycompletely Master and Doctor in his art. Thus
the reader will observe, that Chaucer makes
every one of his characters perfect in his
kind, every one is an Antique Statue; the
image of a class, and not of an imperfect in–individual
dividualindividual.
This groupegroup also would furnish substantial
matter, on which volumes might be written.
The Franklin is one who keeps open table,
who is the genius of eating and drinking, the
Bacchus; as the Doctor of Physic is the Es–Esculapius
culapiusAesculapius, the Host is the Silenus, the Squire
is the Apollo, the Miller is the Hercules, &c.
Chaucer's characters are a description of the
eternal Principles that exist in all ages. The
Franklin is voluptuousness itself most nobly
pourtrayedportrayed:
"It snewed in his house of meat and drink."The original text reads "meate and drinke" rather than "meat and drink" (Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").
The Plowman is simplicity itself, with wis–wisdom
domwisdom and strength for its stamina. Chaucer has
divided the ancient character of Hercules be–between
tweenbetween his Miller and his Plowman. Benevo–Benevolence
lenceBenevolence is the plowman's great characteristic, he is
thin with excessive labourlabor, and not with old
age, as some have supposed.
"He would thresh and thereto dike and delve
For Christe's sake, for every poore wight,
Withouten hire, if it lay in his might."
Visions of these eternal principles or charac–characters
terscharacters of human life appear to poets, in all ages;
the Grecian gods were the ancient Cherubim of
PhœniciaPhoenicia; but the Greeks, and since them
the Moderns, have neglected to subdue the gods
of Priam. These Gods are visions of the eter–eternal
naleternal attributes, or divine names, which, when
erected into gods, become destructive to hu–humanity
manityhumanity. They ought to be the servants, and
not the masters of man, or of society. They
ought to be made to sacrifice to Man, and
not man compelled to sacrifice to them; for
when separated from man or humanity, who
is Jesus the Saviour, the vine of eternity, they
are thieves and rebels, they are destroyers.
The Plowman of Chaucer is Hercules in his
supreme eternal state, divested of his spectrous
shadow; which is the Miller, a terrible fellow,
such as exists in all times and places, for the
trial of men, to astonish every neighbourhoodneighborhood,
with brutal strength and courage, to get richA stray mark appears to the left of the word "with". Bentley notes that "a Black quad shows in the left margin" (*Writings* volume 2 page 1694n18).
and powerful to curb the pride of Man.
The Reeve and the Manciple are two cha–characters
racterscharacters of the most consummate worldly wis–wisdom
domwisdom. The Shipman, or Sailor, is a similar ge–genius
niusgenius of Ulyssean art; but with the highest cou–courage
ragecourage superadded.
The Citizens and their Cook are each leaders
of a class. Chaucer has been somehow made
to number four citizens, which would make
his whole company, himself included, thirty–
one. But he says there was but nine and
twenty in his company.
"Full nine and twenty in a company."The original text reads "Well nine and twentie" rather than "Full nine and twenty" (Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").
The Webbe, or Weaver, and the Tapiser,
or Tapestry Weaver, appear to me to be the
same person; but this is only an opinion, for
full nine and twenty may signify one more or
less. But I dare say that Chaucer wrote "A
Webbe Dyer," that is a Cloth Dyer.
"A Webbe Dyer and a Tapiser,"The original text reads "a webbe, a dier" rather than "A Webbe Dyer" (Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").
The Merchant cannot be one of the Three
Citizens, as his dress is different, and his cha–character
ractercharacter is more marked, whereas Chaucer says of
his rich citizens:
"All were yclothed in o liverielivery."The original text reads "lyuere" rather than "liverie" (Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").
The characters of Women Chaucer has di–divided
videddivided into two classes, the Lady Prioress and
the Wife of Bath. Are not these leaders of
the ages of men? The lady prioress, in some
ages, predominates; and in some the wife of
Bath, in whose character Chaucer has been
equally minute and exact; because she is also
a scourge and a blight. I shall say no more of
her, nor expose what Chaucer has left hidden;
let the young reader study what he has said of
her: it is useful as a scare-crow. There are of
such characters born too many for the peace of
the world.
I come at length to the Clerk of Oxenford.
This character varies from that of Chaucer, as
the contemplative philosopher varies from the
poetical genius. There are always these two
classes of learned sages, the poetical and the
philosophical. The painter has put them side
by side, as if the youthful clerk had put him–himself
selfhimself under the tuition of the mature poet. Let
the Philosopher always be the servant and scho-scholar
larscholar of inspiration and all will be happy.
Such are the characters that compose this
Picture, which was painted in self-defenceself-defense
against the isolent and envious imputation of
unfitness for finished and scientific art; and
this imputation, most artfully and industriously
endeavoured to be propagated among the pub-public
licpublic by ignorant hirelings. The painter courts
comparison with his competitors, who, having
received fourteen hundred guineas and more
from the profits of his designs, in that well-
known work, Designs for Blair's Grave, have left
him to shift for himself, while others, more obe-obedient
dientobedient to an employer's opinions and directions,
are employed, at a great expenceexpense, to produce
works, in succession to his, by which they ac-acquired
quiredacquired public patronage. This has hitherto been
his lot—to get patronage for others and then to be
left and neglected, and his work, which gained
that patronage, cried down as eccentricity and
madness; as unfinished and neglected by the
artist's violent temper, he is sure the works now
exhibited, will give the lie to such aspersions.
Those who say that men are led by interest
are knaves. A knavish character will often
say, of what interest is it to me to do so and
so? I answer, of none at all, but the con-contrary
trarycontrary, as you well know. It is of malice and
envy that you have done this; hence I am
aware of you, because I know that you act
not from interest but from malice, even to your
own destruction. It is therefore become a
duty which Mr. B.Blake owes to the Public, who
have always recognized him, and patronized
him, however hidden by artifices, that he should
not suffer such things to be done or be hin-hindered
deredhindered from the public Exhibition of his finished
productions by any calumnies in future.
The character and expression in this picture
could never have been produced with Ruben's
light and shadow, or with Rembrandt's, or any
thing Venetian or Flemish. The Venetian
and Flemish practice is broken lines, broken
masses, and broken colourscolors. Mr. B.Blake's practice
is unbroken lines, unbroken masses, and un-unbroken
brokenunbroken colourscolors. Their art is to lose form, his
art is to find form, and to keep it. His arts are
opposite to theirs in all things.
As there is a class of men, whose whole de-delight
lightdelight is in the destruction of men, so there
is a class of artists, whose whole art and science
is fabricated for the purpose of destroying art.
Who these are is soon known: "by their works
ye shall know them." All who endeavourendeavor to
raise up a style against RafaelRaphael, Mich. AngeloMichelangelo,
and the Antique; those who separate Painting
from Drawing; who look if a picture is well
Drawn; and, if it is, immediately cry out, that
it cannot be well ColouredColored—those are the men.
But to shewshow the stupidity of this class of
men, nothing need be done but to examine my
rival's prospectus.
The first two characters in Chaucer, the
Knight and the Squire, he has put among his
rabble; and indeed his prospectus calls the
Squire the fop of Chaucer's age. Now hear
Chaucer.
"Of his Stature, he was of even length,
And wonderly deliver, and of great strength;
And he had be sometime in Chivauchy,The original text reads "chiuauchie" rather than "Chivauchy" (Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").
In Flanders, in Artois, and in Picardy,The original text reads "Flaunders" rather than "Flanders," and "Picardie" rather than "Picardy" (Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").
And borne him well as of so litele space."
Was this a fop?
"Well could he sit a horse, and fairefair ride,The original text reads "coud" rather than "could," and "sitte on a" rather than "sit a" (Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").
He could songs make, and eke well inditeThe original text reads "endite" rather than "indite" (Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").
Just, and eke dance, pourtrayportray, and well write.The original text reads "daunce, portray" rather than "dance, pourtray" (Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").
Was this a fop?

"CurteisCourteous he was, and meek, and serviceable;The original text reads "he was, lowly, and seruisable" rather than "he was, and meek, and serviceable" (Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").
And kerft before his fader at the table."The original text reads "kerfte" rather than "kerft"(Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").
Was this a fop?
It is the same with all his characters; he has
done all by chance, or perhaps his fortune, mo–money
neymoney, money. According to his prospectus he has
Three Monks; these he cannot find in Chau–Chaucer
cerChaucer, who has only One Monk, and that no
vulgar character, as he has endeavoured to
make him. When men cannot read they should
not pretend to paint. To be sure Chaucer is
a little difficult to him who has only blundered
over novels and catchpenny trifles of book–booksellers
sellersbooksellers. Yet a little pains ought to be taken
even by the ignorant and weak. He has put
The Reeve, a vulgar fellow, between his
Knight and Squire, as if he was resolved to go
contrary in every thing to Chaucer, who says
of the Reeve:
"And ever he rode hinderest of the routroute."The original text reads "route" rather than "rout" (Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").
In this manner he has jumbled his dumb
dollies together, and is praised by his equals
for it; for both himself and his friend are
equally masters of Chaucer's language. They
both think that the Wife of Bath is a young
beautiful blooming damsel; and H——Hoppner says,
that she is the Fair Wife of Bath, and that the
Spring appears in her Cheeks. Now hear what
Chaucer has made her say of herself, who is no
modest one,
"But Lord when it remembereth meThe original text reads "lord Christ" rather than "Lord", and "remembreth" rather than "remembereth" (Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").
Upon my youth and on my jollity,The original text reads "and my iolite" rather than "and on my jollity" (Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").
It tickleth me about the heart root.The original text reads "hart" rather than "heart" (Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").
Unto this day it doth my heart boot,
That I have had my world as in my time;The original text reads "woll" rather than "world" (Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").
But age, alas, that all will envenime,
Hath me bireftbereft, my beauty and my pith
Let go; farewell: the devil go therewith,The original text reads "Devill" rather than "Devil" (Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").
The flower is gone, there is no more to tell.The original text reads "gon" rather than "gone," and "there nis" rather than "there is" (Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").

The bran, as best, I can, I now mote sell;The original text reads "as best I can I now mote I sell" rather than "as best, I can, I now mote sell" (Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").
And yet, to be right merry, will I fond,The original text reads "But yet" rather than "And yet," and "mery woll" rather than "merry, will" (Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").
Now forth to tell of my fourth husband."The original text reads "husbond" rather than "husband" (Chaucer, *Works*, Speght 1687 ed. "Author's Prologue").
She has had four husbands, a fit subject for
this painter; yet the painter ought to be very
much offended with his friend H——, who has
called his "a common scene," "and very or–ordinary
dinaryordinary forms;" which is the truest part of all,
for it is so, and very wretchedly so indeed.
What merit can there be in a picture of which
such words are spoken with truth.
But the prospectus says that the Painter has
represented Chaucer himself as a knave, who
thrusts himself among honest people, to make
game of and laugh at them; though I must
do justice to the painter, and say that he has
made him look more like a fool than a knave.
But it appears, in all of the writings of Chaucer,
and particularly in his Canterbury Tales, that
he was very devout, and paid respect to true
enthusiastic superstition. He has laughed at
his knaves and fools as I do now. But he has
respected his True Pilgrims, who are a major–majority
itymajority of his company, and are not thrown toge–together
thertogether in the random manner that Mr. S——Stothard has
done. Chaucer has no wherenowhere called the Plow–Plowman
manPlowman old, worn out with age and labourlabor, as the
prospectus has represented him, and says, that
the picture has done so too. He is worn down
with labourlabor, but not with age. How spots of
brown and yellow, smeared about at random,
can be either young or old, I cannot see. It
may be an old man; it may be a young one;
it may be any thing that a prospectus pleases.
But I know that where there are no lineaments
there can be no character. And what connois–connoisseurs
seursconnoisseurs call touch, I know by experience, must
be the destruction of all character and expres–expression
sionexpression, as it is of every lineament.
The scene of Mr. S——'s Picture is by
Dulwich Hills, which was not the way to Can–Canterbury
terburyCanterbury; but, perhaps the painter thought he
would give them a ride round about, because
they were a burlesque set of scare-crows, not
worth any man's respect or care.
But the painter's thoughts being always up–upon
onupon gold, he has introduced a character that
Chaucer has not; namely, a Goldsmith; for
so the prospectus tells us. Why has he intro–introduced
ducedintroduced a Goldsmith, and what is the wit of it,
the prospectus does not explain. But it takes
care to mention the reserve and modesty of
the Painter; this makes a good epigram
enough.
"The fox, the owl, the spider, and the mole,
By sweet reserve and modesty get fat."
But the prospectus tells us, that the painter
has introduced a Sea Captain; Chaucer has a
Ship-man, a Sailor, a Trading Master of a Ves–Vessel
selVessel, called by courtesy Captain, as every master
of a boat is; but this does not make him a Sea
Captain. Chaucer has purposely omitted such a
personage, as it only exists in certain periods:
it is the soldier by sea. He who would be a Sol–Soldier
dierSoldier in inland nations is a sea captain in com–commercial
mercialcommercial nations.
All is misconceived, and its mis-execution is
equal to its misconception. I have no objec–objection
tionobjection to Rubens and Rembrandt being employed,
or even to their living in a palace; but it shall
not be at the expence of RafaelRaphael and MichaelMichelangelo
AngeloMichelangelo living in a cottage, and in contempt
and derision. I have been scorned long enough
by these fellows, who owe to me all they
have; it shall be so no longer.
I found them blind, I taught them how to see;
And, now, they know me not, nor yet themselves.
NUMBER IV4.

l.hi: The Bard, from Gray.

lg.l: On a rock, whose haughty brow
Frown'dFrowned o'erover old Conway's foaming flood,
Robed in the sable garb of woe,
With haggard eyes the Poet stood,
Loose his beard, and hoary hair
Stream'dStreamed like a meteor to the troubled air.
Weave the warp, and weave the woof,
The winding sheet of Edward's race.
Weaving the winding sheet of Edward's race
by means of sounds of spiritual music and its
accompanying expressions of articulate speech
is a bold, and daring, and most masterly con–conception
ceptionconception, that the public have embraced and
approved with avidity. Poetry consists in
these conceptions; and shall Painting be con–confined
finedconfined to the sordid drudgery of fac–similefacsimile re–representations
presentationsrepresentations of merely mortal and perishing
substances, and not be as poetry and music are,
elevated into its own proper sphere of inven–invention
tioninvention and visionary conception? No, it shall
not be so! Painting, as well as poetry and
music, exists and exults in immortal thoughts.
If Mr. B.Blake's Canterbury Pilgrims had been done
by any other power than that of the poetic
visionary, it would have been as dull as his
adversary's.
The Spirits of the murdered bards assist in
weaving the deadly woof.
With me in dreadful harmony they join,
And weave, with bloody hands, the tissue of thy line.
The connoisseurs and artists who have made
objections to Mr. B.Blake's mode of representing
spirits with real bodies, would do well to con–consider
siderconsider that the Venus, the Minerva, the Jupiter,

the Apollo, which they admire in Greek stastatues To the right of the letters "sta" appears an illegible mark instead of a hyphen for the word "statues". Bentley notes that "the hyphen in 'statues' at the end of page 36 appears to be broken" (*Writings* volume 2 pages 1694-1695n25).
tuesstatues, are all of them representations of spiritual
existences of God's immortal, to the mortal pe–perishing
rishingperishing organ of sight; and yet they are embo–embodied
diedembodied and organized in solid marble. Mr. B.Blake
requires the same latitude and all is well. The
Prophets describe what they saw in Vision as
real and existing men whom they saw with
their imaginative and immortal organs; the
Apostles the same; the clearer the organ the
more distinct the object. A Spirit and a Vision
are not, as the modern philosophy supposes, a
cloudy vapourvapor or a nothing: they are organ–organized
izedorganized and minutely articulated beyond all that
the mortal and perishing nature can produce.
He who does not imagine in stronger and bet–better
terbetter lineaments, and in stronger and better light
than his perishing mortal eye can see does not
imagine at all. The painter of this work as–asserts
sertsasserts that all his imaginations appear to him in–infinitely
finitelyinfinitely more perfect and more minutely organ–organized
izedorganized than any thing seen by his mortal eye. Spi–Spirits
ritsSpirits are organized men: Moderns wish to draw
figures without lines, and with great and heavy
shadows; are not shadows more unmeaning
than lines, and more heavy? O who can
doubt this!
King Edward and his Queen ElenorEleanor are
prostrated, with their horses, at the foot of a
rock on which the Bard stands; prostrated by
the terrors of his harp on the margin of the
river Conway, whose waves bear up a corse of
a slaughtered bard at the foot of the rock.
The armies of Edward are seen winding among
the mountains.
"He wound with toilsome march his long array."
Mortimer and Gloucester lie spell bound be–behind
hindbehind their king.
The execution of this picture is also in Wa–Water
terWater ColoursColors, or Fresco.
NUMBER V5.

l.hi: The Ancient Britons.
In the last Battle of King Arthur only Three
Britons escaped, these were the Strongest Man,
the Beautifullest Man, and the Ugliest Man;
these three marched through the field unsub–unsubdued
duedunsubdued, as Gods, and the Sun of Britain sat, but
shall arise again with tenfold splendor when
Arthur shall awake from sleep, and resume
his dominion over earth and ocean.

lg.l: The three general classes of men who are re–represented
presentedrepresented by the most Beautiful, the most
Strong, and the most Ugly, could not be repre–represented
sentedrepresented by any historical facts but those of our
own country, the Ancient Britons; without vio–violating
latingviolating costume. The Britons (say histori anshistorians)
were naked civilized men, learned, studious,
abstruse in thought and contemplation; naked,
simple, plain, in their acts and manners;
wiser than after–ages. They were over–overwhelmed
whelmedoverwhelmed by brutal arms all but a small rem–remnant
nantremnant; Strength, Beauty, and Ugliness es–escaped
capedescaped the wreck, and remain for ever unsub–unsubdued
duedunsubdued, age after age.
The British Antiquities are now in the Ar–Artist's
tist'sArtist's hands; all his visionary contemplations,
relating to his own country and its ancient
glory, when it was as it again shall be, the
source of learning and inspiration. Arthur
was a name for the constellation Arcturus, or
Bootes, the Keeper of the North Pole. And all
the fables of Arthur and his round table; of
the warlike naked Britons; of Merlin; of Ar–Arthur
thurArthur's conquest of the whole world; of his
death, or sleep, and promise to return again;
of the Druid monuments, or temples; of the
pavement of Watling-street; of London stone;
of the caverns in Cornwall, Wales, Derby–Derbyshire
shireDerbyshire, and Scotland; of the Giants of Ireland
and Britain; of the elemental beings, called
by us by the general name of Fairies; and
of these three who escaped, namely, Beauty,
Strength, and Ugliness. Mr B.Blake has in his
hands poems of the highest antiquity. Adam
was a Druid, and Noah; also Abraham was
called to succeed the Druidical age, which be–began
ganbegan to turn allegoric and mental signification
into corporeal command, whereby human sacri–sacrifice
ficesacrifice would have depopulated the earth. All these
things are written in Eden. The artist is an
inhabitant of that happy country; and if everyeverything
thin geverything goes on as it has begun, the worldof ve–vegetation
getationvegetation and generation may expect to be
opened again to Heaven, through Eden, as it
was in the beginning.
The Strong man represents the human sublime.
The Beautiful man represents the human pathe–pathetic
ticpathetic, which was in the wars of Eden divided into
male and female. The Ugly man represents
the human reason. They were originally one
man, who was fourfold; he was self-divided, and
his real humanity slain on the stems of generation,
and the form of the fourth was like the Son of
God. How he became divided is a subject of
great sublimity and pathos. The Artist has
written it under inspiration, and will, if God
please, publish it; it is voluminous, and con–contains
tainscontains the ancient history of Britain, and the
world of Satan and of Adam.
In the mean time he has painted this Picture,
which supposes that in the reign of that Bri–British
tishBritish Prince, who lived in the fifth century,
there were remains of those naked Heroes, in
the Welch Mountains; they are there now,
Gray saw them in the person of his bard on
Snowdon; there they dwell in naked simplici–simplicity
tysimplicity; happy is he who can see and converse
with them above the shadows of generation
and death. The giant Albion, was Patriarch
of the Atlantic, he is the Atlas of the Greeks,
one of those the Greeks called Titans. The
stories of Arthur are the acts of Albion, ap–applied
pliedapplied to a Prince of the fifth century, who
conquered Europe, and held the Empire of
the world in the dark age, which the Romans
never again recovered. In this Picture, be–believing
lievingbelieving with Milton, the ancient British His–History
toryHistory, Mr. B.Blake has done, as all the ancients did,
and as all the moderns, who are worthy of
fame, given the historical fact in its poetical
vigourvigor; so as it always happens, and not in
that dull way that some Historians pretend,
who being weakly organized themselves, can–cannot
notcannot see either miracle or prodigy; all is to
them a dull round of probabilities and possi–possibilities
bilitiespossibilities; but the history of all times and pla–places
cesplaces, is nothing else but improbabilites and im–impossibilities
possibilitiesimpossibilities; what we should say, was impos–impossible
sibleimpossible if we did not see it always before our
eyes.
The antiquities of every Nation under Hea–Heaven
venHeaven, is no less sacred than that of the Jews.
They are the same thing as Jacob Bryant,
and all antiquaries have proved. How other
antiquities came to be neglected and disbeliev–disbelieved
eddisbelieved, while those of the Jews are collected and
arranged, is an enquiry, worthy of both the
Antiquarian and the Divine. All had origi–originally
nallyoriginally one language, and one religion, this was
the religion of Jesus, the everlasting Gospel.
Antiquity preaches the Gospel of Jesus. The
reasoning historian, turner and twister of
causes and consequences, such as Hume,
Gibbon and Voltaire; cannot with all their
artifice, turn or twist one fact or disarrange
self evident action and reality. Reasons and
opinions concerning acts, are not history.
Acts themselves alone are history, and these
are neither the exclusive property of Hume,
Gibbon nor Voltaire, Echard, Rapin, Plu–Plutarch
tarchPlutarch, nor Herodotus. Tell me the Acts, O
historian, and leave me to reason upon them
as I please; away with your reasoning and
your rubbish. All that is not action is not
worth reading. Tell me the What; I do not
want you to tell me the Why, and the How; I
can find that out myself, as well as you can,
and I will not be fooled by you into opinions,
that you please to impose, to disbelieve what
you think improbable or impossible. His
opinions, who does not see spiritual agency,
is not worth any man's reading; he who re–rejects
jectsrejects a fact because it is improbable, must re–reject
jectreject all History and retain doubts only.
It has been said to the Artist, take the Apollo
for the model of your beautiful Man and the
Hercules for your strong Man, and the Danc–Dancing
ingDancing Fawn for your Ugly Man. Now he comes
to his trial. He knows that what he does is not
inferior to the grandest Antiques. Superior
they cannot be, for human power cannot go
beyond either what he does, or what they have
done, it is the gift of God, it is inspiration
and vision. He had resolved to emulate those
precious remains of antiquity he has done so
and the result you behold; his ideas of
strength and beauty have not been greatly
different. Poetry as it exists now on earth,
in the various remains of ancient authors,
Music as it exists in old tunes or melodies,
Painting and Sculpture as it exists in the re–remains
mainsremains of Antiquity and in the works of more
modern genius, is Inspiration, and cannot be
surpassed; it is perfect and eternal. Milton,
ShakspeareShakespeare, Michael AngeloMichelangelo, RafaelRaphael, the
finest specimens of Ancient Sculpture and
Painting, and Architecture, Gothic, Grecian,
HindooHindu and Egyptian, are the extent of the
human mind. The human mind cannot go
beyond the gift of God, the Holy Ghost. To
suppose that Art can go beyond the finest spe–specimens
cimensspecimens of Art that are now in the world, is not
knowing what Art is; it is being blind to the
gifts of the spirit.
It will be necessary for the Painter to say
something concerning his ideas of Beauty,
Strength and Ugliness.
The Beauty that is annexed and appended
to folly, is a lamentable accident and error of
the mortal and perishing life; it does but sel–seldom
domseldom happen; but with this unnatural mixture
the sublime Artist can have nothing to do; it
is fit for the burlesque. The Beauty proper
for sublime art, is lineaments, or forms and
features that are capable of being the recepta–receptacles
clesreceptacles of intellect; accordingly the Painter has
given in his beautiful man, his own idea of in–intellectual
tellectualintellectual Beauty. The face and limbs that
deviates or alters least, from infancy to old
age, is the face and limbs of greatest Beauty
and perfection.
The Ugly likewise, when accompanied and
annexed to imbecility and disease, is a subject
for burlesque and not for historical grandeur;
the Artist has imagined his Ugly man; one
approaching to the beast in features and form,
his forehead small, without frontals; his jaws
large; his nose high on the ridge, and nar–narrow
rownarrow; his chest and the stamina of his make,
comparatively little, and his joints and his ex–extremities
tremitiesextremities large; his eyes with scarce any
whites, narrow and cunning, and every thing
tending toward what is truly Ugly; the inca–incapability
pabilityincapability of intellect.
The Artist has considered his strong Man
as a receptacle of Wisdom, a sublime energi–energizer
zerenergizer; his features and limbs do not spindle out
into length, without strength, nor are they
too large and unwieldy for his brain and and bo–bosom
sombosom. Strength consists in accumulation of
power to the principal seat, and from thence
a regular gradation and subordination; strength
is compactness, not extent nor bulk.
The strong Man acts from conscious supe–superiority
rioritysuperiority, and marches on in fearless dependance
on the diving decrees, raging with the inspira–inspirations
tionsinspirations of a prophetic mind. The Beautiful
Man acts from duty, and anxious solicitude for
the fates of those for whom he combats. The
Ugly Man acts from love of carnage, and de–delight
lightdelight in the savage barbarities of war, rush–rushing
ingrushing with sportive precipitation into the very
teeth of the affrighted enemy.
The Roman Soldiers rolled together in a
heap before them: "Like the rolling thing
before the whirlwind;" each shewshow a different
character, and a different expression of fear,
or revenge, or envy, or blank horror, or
amazement, or devout wonder and unresisting
awe.
The dead and the dying, Britons naked,
mingled with armed Romans, strew the field
beneath. Among these, the last of the Bards
who were capable of attending warlike deeds,
is seen falling, outstretched among the dead There is an unclear mark between "among" and "the" that Bentley notes is a "Black quad" (*Writings* volume 2 page 1695n37).
and the dying; singing to his harp in the
pains of death.
Distant among the mountains, are Druid
Temples, similar to Stone Henge. The Sun
sets behind the mountains, bloody with the
day of battle.
The flush of health in flesh, exposed to the
open air, nourished by the spirits of forests
and floods, in that ancient happy period, which
history has recorded, cannot be like the sick–sickly
lysickly daubs of Titian or Rubens. Where will
the copier of nature, as it now is, find a
civilized man, who has been accustomed to go
naked. Imagination only, can furnish us with
colouringcoloring appropriate, such as is found in the
Frescos of RafaelRaphael and Michael AngeloMichelangelo: the
disposition of forms always directs colouringcoloring
in works of true art. As to a modern Man
stripped from his load of cloathing, he is like a
dead corpse. Hence Rubens, Titian, Correg–Correggio
gioCorreggio, and all of that class, are like leather and
chalk; their men are like leather, and their
women like chalk, for the disposition of their
forms will not admit of grand colouringcoloring; in
Mr. B.Blake's Britons, the blood is seen to circulate
in their limbs; he defies competition in colour–colouring
ingcoloring.
NUMBER VI6.

l.hi: A Spirit vaulting from a cloud to turn and
wind a fiery Pegasus— ShakspeareShakespeare. The Horse
of Intellect is leaping from the cliffs of Memory
and Reasoning; it is a barren Rock: it is also
called the Barren Waste of Locke and Newton.

lg.l: THIS Picture was done many years ago, and
fortunately or rather providentially he left it
unblotted and unblurred, although molested
continually by blotting and blurring demons;
but he was also compelled to leave it unfinish–unfinished
edunfinished for reasons that will be shewnshown in the follow–following
ingfollowing.

desc.objtitle: Page 52 Number VII7 Number VIII8, Object 56 (Bentley 52)

lg.l: NUMBER VII7.

l.hi: The Goats, an experiment Picture.

lg.l: THE subject is taken from the Missionary
Voyage and varied from the literal fact, for the
sake of picturesque scenery. The savage
girls had dressed themselves with vine leaves,
and some goats on board the missionary ship
stripped them off presently. This Picture was
painted at intervals, for experiment, with the
colourscolors, and is labouredlabored to a superabundant
blackness; it has however that about it, which
may be worthy the attention of the Artist and
Connoisseur for reasons that follow.
NUMBER VIII8.

l.hi: The spiritual Preceptor, an experiment
Picture.

lg.l: THIS subject is taken from the visions of
Emanuel Swedenborg. Universal Theology,
No. 623. The Learned, who strive to ascend
into Heaven by means of learning, appear to
Children like dead horses, when repelled by
the celestial spheres. The works of this vi–visionary
sionaryvisionary are well worthy the attention of
Painters and Poets; they are foundations for
grand things; the reason they have not been
more attended to, is, because corporeal demons
have gained a predominance; who the leaders
of these are, will be shewnshown below. Unworthy
Men who gain fame among Men, continue to
govern mankind after death, and in their spiri–spiritual
tualspiritual bodies, oppose the spirits of those, who
worthily are famous; and as Swedenborg ob–observes
servesobserves, by entering into disease and excrement,
drunkenness and concupiscence, they possess
themselves of the bodies of mortal men, and
shut the doors of mind and of thought, by
placing Learning above Inspiration. O Artist!
you may disbelieve all this, but it shall be at
your own peril.
NUMBER IX9.

l.hi: Satan calling up his Legions, from Milton's
Paradise Lost; a composition for a more per–perfect
fectperfect Picture, afterward executed for a Lady
of high rank. An experiment Picture.

lg.l: THIS Picture was likewise painted at intervals,
for experiment on colourscolors, without any oily
vehicle; it may be worthy of attention, not
only on account of its composition, but of the
great labourlabor which has been bestowed on it,
that is, three or four times as much as would
have finished a more perfect Picture; the la–labour
bourlabor has destroyed the lineaments, it was
with difficulty brought back again to a cer–certain
taincertain effect, which it had at first, when all the
lineaments were perfect.
These Pictures, among numerous others
painted for experiment, were the result of
temptations and perturbations, labouringlaboring to des–destroy
troydestroy Imaginative power, by means of that in–infernal
fernalinfernal machine, called Chiaro Oscuro, in
the hands of Venetian and Flemish Demons;
whose enmity to the Painter himself, and to all
Artists who study in the Florentine and Ro–Roman
manRoman Schools, may be removed by an exhibi–exhibition
tionexhibition and exposure of their vile tricks. They
cause that every thingeverything in art shall become a
Machine. They cause that the execution
shall be all blocked up with brown shadows.
They put the original Artist in fear and doubt
of his own original conception. The spirit
of Titian was particularly active, in raising
doubts concerning the possibility of executing
without a model,and when once he had raised the
doubt, it became easy for him to snatch away
the vision time after time, for when the Artist
took his pencil, to execute his ideas, his power
of imagination weakened so much, and dark–darkened
eneddarkened, that memory of nature and of Pictures
of the various Schools possessed his mind, in–instead
steadinstead of appropriate execution, resulting from
the inventions; like walking in another man's
style, or speaking or looking in another man's
style and manner, unappropriate and repug–repugnant
nantrepugnant to your own individual character; tor–tormenting
mentingtormenting the true Artist, till he leaves the Flo–Florentine
rentineFlorentine, and adopts the Venetian practice, or
does as Mr. B. Blake has done, has the courage to
suffer poverty and disgrace, till he ultimately
conquers.
Rubens is a most outrageous demon, and by
infusing the remembrances of his Pictures,
and style of execution, hinders all power of
individual thought: so that the man who is
possessed by this demon, loses all admiration of
any other Artist, but Rubens, and those who
were his imitators and journeymen, he causes
to the Florentine and Roman Artist fear to
execute; and though the original conception
was all fire and animation, he loads it with
hellish brownness, and blocks up all its gates
of light, except one, and that one he closes
with iron bars, till the victim is obliged to
give up the Florentine and Roman practice,
and adopt the Venetian and the Flemish.
Correggio is a soft and effeminate and con–consequently
sequentlyconsequently a most cruel demon, whose whole
delight is to cause endless labourlabor to whoever
suffers him to enter his mind. The story that
is told in all Lives of the Painters about Cor–Correggio
reggioCorreggio being poor and but badly paid for his
Pictures, is altogether false; he was a petty
Prince, in Italy, and employed numerous
Journeymen in manufacturing (as Rubens and
Titian did) the Pictures that go under his
name. The manual labourlabor in these Pictures
of Correggio is immense, and was paid for
originally at the immense prices that those
who keep manufactories of art always charge
to their employers, while they themselves pay
their journeymen little enough. But though
Correggio was not poor, he will make any
true artist so, who permits him to enter his
mind, and take posession of his affections;
he infuses a love of soft and even tints with–without
outwithout boundaries, and of endless reflected lights,
that confuse one another, and hinder all cor–correct
rectcorrect drawing from appearing to be correct;
for if one of Rafael Raphael or Michael AngeloMichelangelo's
figures was to be traced, and Correggio's re–reflections
flectionsreflections and refractions to be added to it, there
would soon be an end of proportion and
strength, and it would be weak, and pappy,
and lumbering, and thick headed, like his own
works; but then it would have softness and
evenness, by a twelvemonth's labourlabor, where
a month would with judgment have finished
it better and higher; and the poor wretch who
executed it, would be the Correggio that the
life writers have written of: a drudge and a
miserable man, compelled to softness by po–poverty
vertypoverty. I say again, O Artist, you may disbe–disbelieve
lievedisbelieve all this, but it shall be at your own
peril.
Note. These experiment Pictures have
been bruizedbruised and knocked about, without
mercy, to try all experiments.
NUMBER X10.

l.hi: The BraminsBrahmins.—A Drawing.

lg.l: The subject is, Mr. WilkinCharles Wilkins, translating the Bentley (*Writings* volume 2 page 859n101) identifies Mr. Wilkin as Charles Wilkins.
GeetaBhagavad Gita; an ideal design, suggested by the
first publication of that part of the HindooHindu
Scriptures, translated by Mr. WilkinCharles Wilkins. I un–understand
derstandunderstand that my Costume is incorrect, but
in this I plead the authority of the ancients,
who often deviated from the Habits, to pre–preserve
servepreserve the Manners, as in the instance of
Laocoon, who, though a priest, is represented
naked.

desc.objtitle: Page 60, Number XI11., Number XII12., Number XIII13., Number XIV14., Object 64 (Bentley 60)

lg.l: NUMBER XI11.

l.hi: The body of Abel found by Adam and Eve;
Cain, who was about to bury it, fleeing from
the face of his Parents.—A Drawing.

lg.l: NUMBER XII12.

l.hi: The Soldiers casting lots for Christ's Garment.
—A Drawing.

lg.l: NUMBER XIII13.

l.hi: Jacob's Ladder.—A Drawing.

lg.l: NUMBER XIV14.

l.hi: The Angels hovering over the Body of Jesus
in the Sepulchre.— A Drawing.

lg.l: The above four drawings the Artist wishes
were in Fresco, on an enlarged scale to orna-ornament
mentornament the altars of churches, and to make
England like Italy, respected by respectable
men of other countries on account of Art.
It is not the want of genius, that can hereafter
be laid to our charge, the Artist who has done
these Pictures and Drawings will take care of
that; let those who govern the Nation, take
care of the other. The times require that
every one should speak out boldly; England
expects that every man should do his duty, in
Arts, as well as in Arms, or in the Senate.
NUMBER XV15.

l.hi: Ruth.—A Drawing.

lg.l: THIS Design is taken from that most pathetic
passage in the Book of Ruth, where Naomi
having taken leave of her daughters in law,
with intent to return to her own country;
Ruth cannot leave her, but says, "Whither
thou goest I will go; and where thou lodgest
I will lodge, thy people shall be my people,
and thy God my God: where thou diest I will
die, and there will I be buried; God do so to
me and more also, if ought but death part thee
and me."
The distinction that is made in modern
times between a Painting and a Drawing pro–proceeds
ceedsproceeds from ignorance of art. The merit of a
Picture is the same as the merit of a Drawing.
The dawberdauber dawbsdaubs his Drawings; he who
draws his Drawings draws his Pictures. There
is no difference between RafaelRaphael's Cartoons and
his Frescos, or Pictures, except that the Fres–Frescos
cosFrescos, or Pictures, are more finished. When
Mr. B.Blake formerly painted in oil colourscolors his Pic–Pictures
turesPictures were shewnshown to certain painters and con–connoisseurs
noisseursconnoisseurs, who said that they were very admi–admirable
rableadmirable Drawings on canvass; but not Pictures:
but they said the same of RafaelRaphael's Pictures.
Mr. B.Blake thought this the greatest of compliments,
though it was meant otherwise. If losing and
obliterating the outline constitutes a Picture,
Mr. B.Blake will never be so foolish as to do one.
Such art of losing the outlines is the art of
Venice and Flanders; it loses all character,
and leaves what some people call, expression:
but this is a false notion of expression; ex–expression
pressionexpression cannot exist without character as its
stamina; and neither character nor expression
can exist without firm and determinate out–outline
lineoutline. Fresco Painting is susceptible of higher
finishing than Drawing on Paper, or than any
other method of Painting. But he must have
a strange organization of sight who does not
prefer a Drawing on Paper to a DawbingDaubing in
Oil by the same master, supposing both to be
done with equal care.
The great and golden rule of art, as well as
of life, is this: That the more distinct, sharp,
and wirey the bounding line, the more perfect
the work of art; and the less keen and sharp,
the greater is the evidence of weak imitation,
plagiarism, and bungling. Great inventors,
in all ages, knew this: Protogenes and Apelles
knew each other by this line. Rafael Raphael and Mi–Michelangelo
chael Angelo, and Albert DurerAlbrecht Duerer, are known by
this and this alone. The want of this determi–determinate

l.note: The phrase "want of" has been inserted in Blake's hand. Bentley notes that in copies B, C, D, F, G, H, J, L, and O "of want" on lines 11-12, as transcribed here, is struck through and replaced with "want of" in Blake's hand (*Writings* volume 2 page 861n110). See also Erdman page 881.

lg.l: natedeterminate and bounding form evidences the idea of
want in the artist's mind, and the pretence of the
plagiary in all its branches. How do we distin–distinguish
guishdistinguish the oak from the beech, the horse from the
ox, but by the bounding outline? How do we
distinguish one face or countenance from an–another
otheranother, but by the bounding line and its infinite
inflexionsinflections and movements? What is it that
builds a house and plants a garden, but the
definite and determinate? What is it that dis–distinguishes
tinguishesdistinguishes honesty from knavery, but the
hard and wirey line of rectitude and certainty
in the actions and intentions. Leave out this
ln eline and you leave out life itself; all is chaos
again, and the line of the almighty must be
drawn out upon it before man or beast can ex–exist
istexist. Talk no more then of Correggio, or
Rembrandt, or any other of those plagia–plagiaries
riesplagiaries of Venice or Flanders. They were but
the lame imitators of lines drawn by their pre–predecessors
decessorspredecessors, and their works prove themselves
contemptible dis-arranged imitations and blun–blundering
deringblundering misapplied copies.
NUMBER XVI16.

l.hi: The Penance of Jane Shore in Saint Paul's
Church.—A Drawing.

lg.l: THIS Drawing was done above Thirty Years
ago, and proves to the Author, and he thinks
will prove to any discerning eye, that the pro–productions
ductionsproductions of our youth and of our maturer age
are equal in all essential points. If a man is
master of his profession, he cannot be ignorant
that he is so; and if he is not employed by
those who pretend to encourage art, he will
employ himself, and laugh in secret at the
pretencespretenses of the ignorant, while he has every
night dropped into his shoe, as soon as he puts
it off, and puts out the candle, and gets into
bed, a reward for the labourslabors of the day, such
as the world cannot give, and patience and
time await to give him all that the world can
give.
FINIS.

l.note: In the printed edition, this line is a double rule.

textfoot.l: D. N. SHURYDaniel Nathan Shury, PRINTER, BERWICK-STREET,
